Project Description 

 

 

 Viet  Nam  has  experienced  strong  economic  growth,  with  real 
gross  domestic  product  expanding  at  7.8%  in  2002–2006  and 
8.5%  in  2007.  From  1993  to  2007,  poverty  levels  in  Viet  Nam 
dropped  from  over  58%  to  19.5%  and  per  capita  income  more 
than  doubled.  Urban  areas  have  benefited  more—in  2004,  the 
incidence of urban poverty was 13.7% compared to 26.4% in rural 
areas. In recent years, however, growth of aggregate demand has 
outpaced  that  of  aggregate  supply.  The  Government  has  shifted 
its  policy  priorities  from  maintaining  high  rates  of  investment  and 
output  growth  to  curbing  inflation,  reducing  the  trade  and  current 
account deficits, ensuring stable supply of basic food products to 
domestic  markets,  and  enhancing  social  assistance  to  poor  and 
vulnerable segments of the population. 
 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  country  strategy  and 
program  for  Viet  Nam  aims  at  helping  the  Government  reduce 
poverty  to  10%–11%  by  2010  through  (i)  pro-poor  business-led 
economic  growth,  (ii)  social  equity  and  balanced  development, 
and  (iii)  environment  protection  and  management.  The  country 
strategy  and  program  emphasizes,  among  other 
things, 
investment  in  rural  infrastructure,  addressing  the  shortage  of 
skilled workers, support to equity issues, access to basic services, 
and promoting governance. In the past decade, ADB has played a 
major role in Viet Nam’s health sector, in particular in building up 
primary  health  care,  nutrition,  and  communicable  diseases 
control.  ADB,  with  adoption  of  its  long-term  strategic  framework 
2008–2020 (Strategy 2020), will curtail direct support for national 
health sector investment projects to focus more on poverty-related 
assistance  for  achieving  millennium  development  goals,  sector 
governance  and  financing,  infrastructure,  public  goods,  and 
regional cooperation. 
 
The  Government  has  requested  ADB  to  support  the  Health  Care 
in the South Central Coast Region (SCCR) Project, in parallel with 
a  similar  project  of  the  World  Bank  in  the  North  Central  Coast 
Region.  Sector  investment  remains  seriously  underfunded.  The 
Government also wants to improve sector efficiency and is moving 
toward  a  sector  approach.  Accordingly,  the  Project  presents  a 
transition  in  ADB’s  assistance  to  the  health  sector  in  Viet  Nam 
consistent  with  Strategy  2020.  The  Project  will  support  the 
upgrading of provincial health services in eight provinces through 
developing  a  comprehensive  provincial  health  systems  approach 
that will help coordinate all sector sources and uses of funds. The 
Project  will be  followed by  ADB  support  to  a  sector  development 
program for the national sector approach in 2009, currently under 
preparation.

The  SCCR  has  a  population  of  almost  9  million,  including  about 
half a million ethnic minorities. Four of the eight project provinces 
have  poverty  levels  significantly  above  the  national  average  of 
19.5%,  including  Ninh  Thuan  at  45.0%,  Quang  Nam  at  36.3%, 
Quang  Ngai  at  36.1%,  and  Binh  Dinh  at  28.3%.  The  Project 
contributes to poverty reduction by improving health services used 
by  the  poor,  and  will  especially  target  reproductive  health 
interventions  that  benefit  women  and  children.  The  Project  will 
upgrade  or  newly  construct  20  hospitals  (19%  of  all  hospitals  in 
the  region),  5  district  preventive  medicine  centers,  and  the  Ninh 
Thuan  Secondary  Medical  School  for  nursing  and  paramedic 
training.  This  includes  equipping  these  and  other  facilities,  and 
training  in  waste  management  and  infection  control.  It  will  also 
improve  staff  skills  throughout  the  project  area  and  add  128 
specialists and 160 health workers from ethnic communes. Out of 
a total of 1,024 communes in the SCCR, village health care will be 
improved  in  423  remote  communities,  including  223  communes 
classified  as  poor,  and  about  250  ethnic  minority  communes.  Of 
these,  100  ethnic  minority  communes  will  receive  intensified 
health  and  nutrition  promotion  and  better  ability  to  access  health 
care services and health care funds for the poor.

In  terms  of  institutional  benefits,  the  Project  will  support  a 
comprehensive  and 
results-based  provincial  health  system 
development  approach;  and  national  policies  for  (i)  standards  of 
the  design  and  equipping  of  hospitals,  (ii)  a  provincial  human 
resource development system, (iii) managing health care funds for 
the poor, and (iv) standards for provincial planning and budgeting. 
 
Economic  benefits  may  flow  from  reduced  health  care  costs 
through  gains  in  labor  productivity  resulting  from  decreased 
incidence and severity of illness. Out-of-pocket cost savings may 
flow  from  (i)  increased  access  to  health  services  that  reduce 
transport costs, and (ii) more efficient and rational diagnoses and 
treatments that reduce treatment costs. An important cost factor is 
that  caring  for  sick  children  also  reduces  adult  productivity.  The 
Project is estimated to reduce lost working days by an annual 6.5 
million  in  the  SCCR,  valued  at  nearly  $14 million  per  year.  The 
Project’s economic internal rate of return is estimated at 19%, with 
an economic net present value of $20.1 million.   
 
The  provincial  budget  is  the  most  important  of  the  public  sector 
contributions,  as  direct  central  budget  support  for  public  health 
sector  is  relatively  minor.  Allocations  are  driven  by  economic 
growth  and  tax  revenues.  Changing  political  priorities  may  also 
reduce  the  sector  allocation.  Within  the  overall  sector  allocation, 
provincial  governments  also  make  strategic  decisions  on  the 
balance of investments that affect the impacts of provincial health 
systems  and  the  Project.  The  Project  supports  policy  links  with 
MOH  and  provincial  planning  and  budgeting  to  guide  provinces 
toward results-based health system development to achieve more 
effective,  equitable,  and  efficient  health  systems  and  to  monitor 
this  closely.  The  process  is  also  expected  to  contribute  to  the 
national sector approach and aid harmonization.      
 
Several project activities such as improving the quality of hospital 
construction,  waste  management  systems,  and  skills  training  of 
health  staff  are  technically  challenging.  MOH  will  manage  the 
recruitment and fielding of all consultants to ensure that adequate 
technical  support  can  be  provided  to  all  provinces  on  an  as-
needed basis.

procurement  system,  some  delay  in  procurement  is  expected. 
Advance action will help mitigate this risk, and MOH has selected

6. 
Viet Nam has made good progress in improving the health status of its citizens. Between 
2000  and  2005,  the  child  malnutrition  rate  (weight  by  age)  has  been  reduced  from  33.1%  to 
25.2%, the child mortality rate from 42 to 28 child deaths per 1,000 live births, and the maternal 
mortality  ratio  from  95  to  80  maternal  deaths  per  100,000  live  births. 5 However,  disparities 
remain.  Its  population  is  undergoing  a  demographic  and  epidemiological  transition.  By  2014, 
10% of the population will be over 60 years old. Demand for health services is rising rapidly due 
to  such  factors  as  rising  incomes  and  education,  population  aging,  rural–urban  migration,  and 
traffic accidents. However, inequity has also been increasing. Given current trends, the country 
can  only  achieve  its  MDGs  by  2015  if  it  makes  considerable  efforts  to  improve  the  quality  of 
care  and  financial  access  for  the  poor  and  ethnic  minorities  in  lagging  communities  with  high 
mortality, morbidity, and malnutrition rates. In 2005, the infant mortality rate in rural areas was 
still  twice  the  urban  rate.  Health  and  nutrition  indicators  are  much  worse  among  some  ethnic 
groups. In the SCCR, these communes are mostly located in the mountainous hinterland.  
 
7. 
Disease  patterns  are  changing.  In  1976,  infectious  diseases  accounted  for  56%  of 
morbidity, compared to only 26% in 2004, while the share of noninfectious diseases grew from 
43% to 61%, and injuries and accidents from 2% to 13%. The current longevity largely results 
from past efforts to reduce child mortality and promote a healthy lifestyle. These gains may be 
lost  in  a  more  affluent  society,  with  less  attention  to  prevention  and  a  rise  in  diseases  of 
affluence.  Still,  the  battle  for  infectious  diseases  control  is far  from  over  and  needs  continuing 
investment. The prevalence of HIV/AIDS among adults has climbed to 0.5%, and the incidence 
of tuberculosis has not declined recently. Pandemic influenza and other emerging diseases are 
a  constant  threat.  To  address  this  double  burden  of  diseases,  both  major  upgrading  of  health 
services for the general population and targeted support for poor communes are needed.  
 
8. 
Preventive and hospital services are mostly public. Private services mainly contribute to 
curative outpatient care. Viet Nam’s public health system follows the administrative structure of 
the  village,  commune,  district,  provincial,  and  national  levels.  The  Ministry  of  Health  (MOH) 
structure  also  has  three  main  vertical  pillars:  curative,  preventive  and  administrative.  Village 
health workers (VHWs) provide village health care along with private paramedics and volunteers 
of mass organizations. Commune health stations (CHSs) serve up to 10 villages each and have 
at  least  one  trained  health  worker.  District  hospitals,  with 50–100  beds,  provide  basic  hospital 
services  for  a  catchment  area  of  about  100,000  people.  Provincial  hospitals,  with  500–1,000 
beds,  provide  a  range  of  specialized  services  for  about  1  million  people.  MOH  operates  a 
system  of  national  referral  hospitals,  including  in  Da  Nang  City.  The  health  services  are 
complemented by vertical programs, such as for immunization, CDC, and safe motherhood.  
 
9.

health worker. However, 44% of pregnant women received fewer than three antenatal checkups

1. 

Insufficient Health Facilities 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

B. 
 
 
 
Viet Nam’s  public health sector is burdened with an old infrastructure that is physically 
13. 
degraded, poorly equipped, and has inadequate systems for water and waste management and 
infection control. The SCCR has two MOH hospitals (in Da Nang City), 40 provincial hospitals, 
64 district hospitals, 91 polyclinics, and 1,020 CHSs. Appendix 2 provides a sector analysis.  
 
The provincial hospital in Viet Nam provides basic specialist services.9 District hospitals 
14. 
in  Viet  Nam  often  lack  these  services  and  are  bypassed  in  favor  of  the  provincial  hospital. 
Provincial  hospitals  are  typically  overwhelmed  with  both  outpatients  and  inpatients.  The  bed 
occupancy rate in provincial hospitals in the SCCR is about 130%, compared to about 80% in 
district  hospitals.  Hospital  admissions  have  grown  by  about  3%  each  year  between  2000  and 
2005.  Even  so,  the  bed:population  ratio  for  provincial  hospitals  in  the  SCCR  is  about  8  per 
10,000  people.  This  is  slightly  higher  than  the  national  average,  suggesting  that  expanding 
provincial hospitals is not a priority.     
 
15. 
In  terms  of  hospital  services,  three  actions  are  simultaneously  needed  in  the  SCCR: 
(i) replace  old  infrastructure,  (ii)  decongest  provincial  hospitals  by  upgrading  district  hospitals 
while  possibly  adding  a  gatekeeping  function,  and  (iii)  improve  the  quality  and  efficiency  of 
hospital services. On this last point, the hospital inpatient stay is relatively long at an average of 
8  days.  Financial  incentives  drive  hospitals  to  retain  inpatients  and  to  add  beds.  Accordingly, 
financial incentives should be changed to reduce nonessential inpatient stay.   
 
16.  MOH  estimates  that  only  50%  of  hospitals  meet  80%  of  prescribed  equipment 
standards. Just 5% of hospitals have modern X-ray equipment. Despite the long list of partners 
in  each  province  (Appendix  3),  only  30%  of  hospitals  report  having  received  external  aid  for 
equipment. MOH has set out criteria to guide the modernization and standardization of curative 
services. There is a standard list of equipment for every type of health facility. Given increasing 
demand for high-quality health care, this includes certain equipment for advanced diagnostics, 
in particular for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases, cancer, and trauma.  
 
17.  Most  provinces  lack  modern  medical  waste  incinerators  or  do  not  have  established 
procedures  to  coordinate  their  use  among  hospitals.  Lack  of  maintenance,  fuel,  and  other 
equipment and supplies further compromise their efficient use. Special procedures are required 
for  medical  sharps,  contaminated  wastes,  organic  wastes,  hazardous  chemicals,  and 
radioactive  wastes,  along  with  funds  for  staff  training,  supplies,  and  equipment  maintenance. 
MOH  wants  to  see  hospital  waste  management  systems  and  practices  included  in  every 
hospital project (footnote 8). 
 
18. 
Decongesting  public  hospitals  also  requires  better  facilities  for  basic  health  care.  MOH 
plans  to  improve  CHS  facilities  from  its  own  resources.  MOH  has  also  prepared  a  plan  for 
constructing  district  preventive  medicine  centers  (DPMCs)  to  strengthen  preventive  care  at 
commune  level.  These  will  focus  on  infectious  diseases  control,  food  safety,  and  certain 
reproductive health services. MOH is working on a plan to pilot test these centers in the SCCR.

Inadequate Quality of Health Staff 

 
 
19. 
The  quality  of  services  in  health  facilities  depends  greatly  on  staff  performance. 
Evidence from various studies indicates that staff has serious gaps in their knowledge, attitudes, 
and  skills.  There  are  also  staff  imbalances.  MOH  expects  the  provinces  to  take  the  lead  in 
addressing  these  issues.  The  increasingly  complex  health  context,  including  private  sector 
growth,  provides  significant  challenges  to  planning  and  managing  the  health  workforce.  Each 
provincial  health  bureau  (PHB)  is  responsible  for  preparing,  managing,  and  monitoring  human 
resources  development  (HRD)  in  the  province,  for  which  it  is  ill-prepared.  In  addition,  MOH 
undertakes  few  studies  on  HRD  policy  and  management  issues  that  would  provide  valuable 
policy inputs for planning the future health workforce. 
 
Six provincial secondary medical schools (SMSs), Da Nang Medical College, and Ninh 
20. 
Thuan Medical Training Center together provide most of the education and in-service training to 
nurses  and  paramedics  in  the  SCCR.  Most  of  their  teachers  do  not  possess  postgraduate 
qualifications,  however,  and  some  have  only  secondary  level  qualifications.  In  addition,  most 
instruction puts little emphasis on problem solving and skills training. While there is a move in 
this  direction,  most  training  curricula  and  materials  do  not  support  a  skills-based  approach. 
MOH is planning to make SMS education and training more relevant to the daily tasks.   
 
Importantly, there are no established standards for continuing education for any types of 
21. 
staff at any level, including doctors. MOH plans to introduce policies on continuing education for 
those  already  in  the  workforce.10 It  has  recently  initiated  a  new  in-service  training  program  for 
professionals, whereby staff at each level will provide training to staff one level lower. There are 
also  no  established guidelines  for professional  licensure  or  institutional  accreditation,  although 
policies addressing these issues are being developed.11  
 
22. 
The total number and distribution of health staff is fair in the SCCR. For example, 70% of 
CHSs  have  a  doctor  and  almost  all  have  a  female  health  worker.  As  elsewhere  in  Viet  Nam, 
however, there are some important imbalances, including (i) shortage of nurses, (ii) lack of core 
specialists, (iii) lack of health workers with ethnic minority background, and (iv) unwillingness of 
health  personnel  to  serve  in  remote  areas.  MOH  has  set  goals  to  recruit  and  train  increased 
numbers  of  health  staff,  especially  doctors  (core  specialties),  nurses,  technicians,  and 
pharmacists,  as  well  as  to  upgrade  the  quality  of  their  training.  MOH  is  planning  to  provide 
scholarships to suitable ethnic minority candidates to serve their communes.    
 
 
 
23. 
A major thrust of the Government’s health sector plan is to consolidate and complete the 
grassroots  health  care  network  (footnote  8).  This  is  a  priority  for  remote  communes  that  lack 
access to higher level services. MOH plans to finance the upgrading, equipping, and staffing of 
CHSs  from  its  own  sources.  At  village  level,  MOH  aims  to  have  one  female  and  one  male 
trained  VHWs  in  each  village.  Of  the  1,024  communes  in  the  SCCR’s  84  districts,  423  are 
remote or mountainous, including 223 classified as poor, and most of the estimated 250 ethnic 
minority communes. Inadequate knowledge and skills of VHWs is a common issue, and some 
20%  of  remote  villages  lack  competent  VHWs.  Female  VHWs  need  to  be  increased  so  that 
more attention can be given to reproductive health and nutrition.

24.  While  high  mortality  rates  reflect  the  risks  of  living  in  remote  areas,  there  are  other 
important factors. For example, one study showed that nearly half of maternal deaths were due 
to  delays  in  making  decisions,  identifying  mothers  at  risk,  and  providing  essential  treatment 
(footnote 5). While a major cause of this delay is the lack of skilled health workers, low demand 
is  another  factor.  Ethnic  minorities,  in  particular,  tend  to  seek  health  services  less  often, 
averaging 2.3 outpatient visits per year compared to 3.5 for Kinh. Traditions, mistrust, and lack 
of  education  affect  demand.  Thus,  promoting  appropriate  health  and  nutrition  among  minority 
women—and  preferably  by  women  belonging  to  the  same  ethnic  group—is  considered  a 
priority.   
 
25.  While other factors influence access, the out-of-pocket cost of health care is perhaps the 
most significant constraining factor. Utilization of both outpatient and hospital inpatient services 
shows  a  strong  link  with  economic  status.  The  predominance  of  user  fees  at  all  levels  of  the 
health  system,  coupled  with  the  cost  of  drugs  and  indirect  expenses  for  travel  and 
accompanying  family  members,  can  be  a  devastating  financial  burden  for  those  living  at  a 
subsistence level. In 2002, Prime Minister Decision 139 established the HCFP to mitigate these 
financial burdens for the poor, ethnic minorities in 12 mountainous provinces, and residents of 
socioeconomically disadvantaged communes.12  
 
26. 
Subsequent  decisions  provided  for  issuing  health  insurance  cards  to  all  beneficiaries, 
increasing the number of eligible people by raising the poverty line, and an expanded benefits 
package that includes travel cost for referral. HCFP enrollment rose to an estimated 14.9 million 
in  2006—accounting  for  44%  of  the  34.5  million  subscribers  to  all  health  insurance  schemes 
(Appendix 2). But even with its rapid growth, the potential of HCFP has yet to be fully realized. 
Administration  of  the  funds  at  the  provincial  level  has  been  weak  and  inconsistent.  Enrollees 
sometimes  do  not  understand  their  eligibility  or  how  to  access  health  services.  Improving  the 
management of the HCFP is a priority in the region.   
 
 
 
27. 
Given  the  relatively  high  gains  already  made  and  the  growing  complexity  of  health 
system  technology  and  finance,  to achieve  further  improvements  in  health  status will  be  more 
challenging.  It  requires greater  management  sophistication in  planning and  executing  targeted 
programs designed to upgrade the services and reach entrenched populations of the poor and 
underserved.  Beginning  in  1996  with  the  introduction  of  the  State  Budget  Law  (footnote  5), 
provinces  have  had  authority  to  spend  on  provincial  health  services,  with  districts  and 
communes  having  responsibilities  for  services  delegated  to  them  by  the  province.  In  addition, 
the provincial authorities receive central subsidies and have some discretion in determining how 
these are allocated. However, provincial authorities often lack the information and know-how to 
do so effectively.     
 
28. 
Beginning in 2002 with approval of the master plan for the development of the hospital 
network  in  Viet  Nam  for  2005–2010,  policy  changes  were  also  introduced  to  promote

expenditure imbalances. It was replaced by Decree 43 in 2006, which allowed certain hospitals

The quantitative cost-benefit analysis for the Project follows the methodologies outlined 
in ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects (1997). Economic benefits may flow 
from  reduced  health  care  costs  through  gains  in  labor  productivity  resulting  from  decreased 
incidence and severity of illness. Out-of-pocket cost savings may flow from (i) increased access 
to health services that reduce transport costs, and (ii) more efficient and rational diagnoses and 
treatments that reduce treatment costs. An important cost factor is that caring for sick children 
also reduces adult productivity. The Project is estimated to reduce lost workdays by an annual 
average 6.5 million in the SCCR, valued at nearly $14 million per year. The economic internal 
rate of return from this impact is estimated at 19%, and an economic net present value of $20.1 
million is calculated. The economic and financial analysis is in Supplementary Appendix F.

B. 
 
3. 
The public health system is organized in administrative tiers, as well as into three main 
vertical  pillars:  administrative,  curative,  and  preventive.  Public  health  administration  is 
concerned  with  planning  and  budgeting,  management  of  the  health  system,  and  monitoring 
performance.  It  also  has  a  role  in  accreditation  and  inspection  of  private  services.  Preventive 
and hospital services are mostly public. Private services mainly contribute to curative outpatient 
care. About 30,000 private clinics operate nationwide.2 In addition to registered pharmacies and 
drug shops, there are an unknown number of unregistered providers.   
  
4. 
In  2006,  Viet  Nam  had  942  public  hospitals  and  43  private  hospitals  with  a  total  of 
197,686 beds in all health facilities including 132,381 beds in hospitals, or 16 hospital beds per 
10,000  people. 3  The  Ministry  of  Health  (MOH)  managed  21  large  hospitals,  while  local 
authorities managed 921 hospitals (207 specialized, 117 provincial, and 597 district hospitals). 
The  country  also  had  838  polyclinics  and  10,679  commune  health  stations  (CHSs)  linked  to 
village health workers (VHWs). Seventy percent of hospitals have fewer than 100 beds. The 43 
private hospitals account for 4.1% of all hospitals and 2.4% of patient beds.  
 
5. 
Preventive  activities  have  been  centered  at  the  commune  level.  In  recent  years, 
however,  and  stimulated  by  the  increasing  prevalence  of  HIV/AIDS  and  emerging  diseases, 
MOH  developed  a  nationwide  system  of  provincial  preventive  medicine  centers.  It  has  also 
adopted a plan to establish separate district preventive medicine centers (DPMCs). The DPMCs 
would primarily be responsible for infectious diseases control, food safety, certain reproductive 
health services, and environmental health. These facilities receive direct support from MOH.   
 
6. 
The  network  of  health  services  provides  good  coverage  of  essential  services  with  the 
support  of  vertical  programs.  For  example,  98%  of  children  under  1  year  of  age  are  fully 
immunized and 96% of deliveries are attended by a trained health worker. However, there are 
also gaps. Table A2.3 shows that the poor know less about prevention, use services less often, 
and are more dependent on VHWs. It also shows, if these statistics are correct, that there is an 
overdependence on hospitals as the first contact, including in SCCR. Reliable provincial health 
services  indicators  are  not  available.  According  to  MOH,  the  provincial  data  are  not 
representative  and  are  inaccurate.4 The  data  provided  in  Table  A2.4,  therefore,  need  to  be

possible  that  it  is  actually  somewhat  lower  than  these  data  suggest,  in  particular  when 
considering the minorities living in the remote mountain areas in the coastal provinces.

9. 
As  extensive  as  it  is,  Viet  Nam’s  health  infrastructure  has  deteriorated  and  is  poorly 
equipped,  with  inadequate  systems  for  water  and  waste  management  and  infection  control. 
Most provincial hospitals (including those in the SCCR) were constructed 20 or more years ago. 
No  systematic  data  is  collected  on  the  status  and  maintenance  of  facilities,  however,  and 
maintenance  budgets  are  small.  Planning  the  upgrading  and  new  construction  of  public 
hospitals  is  challenging,  given  the  increasing  demand  for  high  level  quality  care,  improving 
physical  and  financial  access,  and  expected  deregulation  of  private  hospital  development  by 
2010.  Bypassing  of  district  hospitals  is  thought  to  be  common,  although  firm  statistics  are 
lacking. A major reason is thought to be the lack of specialty services. MOH wants to address 
the  shortage  of  provincial  hospital  beds  with  specialty  services  by  upgrading  certain  district 
hospitals to regional hospitals serving 2–3 districts. However, such regional hospitals are often 
proposed along main roads in low population areas where land is available. Furthermore, new 
district  hospitals  are  sometimes  being  planned  in  suburban  areas  near  provincial  hospitals. 
Given the tendency to bypass smaller facilities, some form of gatekeeping may be required to 
ensure proper use of facilities at all levels. Inpatient stay is particularly long in the SCCR, which 
is  believed  to  be  linked  to  financial  incentives  rather  than  case  mix.  While  there  is  an  overall 
shortage of hospital beds in the country, including in the SCCR, current facilities could be better 
used by introducing such a gatekeeping system and also by shortening inpatient stays.

10.  MOH estimates that only 50% of hospitals meet 80% or more of prescribed equipment 
standards.  Just  5%  of  hospitals  have  modern  X-ray  equipment,  and  30%  of  hospitals  have 
received overseas development assistance. MOH has set out criteria to guide the modernization 
and standardization of curative services. There is a standard list of equipment for every type of 
health  facility.  Given  increasing  demand  for  high-quality  health  care,  this  includes  certain 
equipment  for  advanced  diagnostics,  in  particular  for  cardiovascular  diseases,  cancer,  and 
trauma.  In  any  hospital  project,  waste  management  systems  and  practices  will  need  to  be 
brought up to current standards, and staff will need to be trained to implement these systems.    
 
E. 
 
11. 
The  departments  of  science  and  training,  organization  and  personnel,  and  therapy, 
along  with  provincial  health  bureaus,  universities,  secondary  medical  schools  (SMSs),  and 
others, are working together to develop a comprehensive human resource development (HRD) 
policy and to strengthen workforce planning, management, and training (footnote 2, p.48). There 
has  been  significant  decentralization  of  responsibility  for  managing  the  health  workforce  over 
recent  years.  Each  provincial  health  department  prepares  an  annual  plan  including  HRD,  and 
particularly training, consistent with the guidelines provided by MOH. Provinces lack the skills to 
plan and manage HRD in an increasingly complex health environment, however, and also lack 
the  analytical  capacity  to  examine  specific  HRD  issues.  This  will  require  strong  collaboration 
with  MOH.  Additional  research  will  be  required  to  support  the  HRD  plan.  However,  local 
research grants rarely get used for researching health systems and policy, as they are directed 
to clinical studies.5   
 
Over the past 5 years, the MOH workforce has grown at 2.28% per year,6 compared to a 
12. 
population growth of 1.37% per annum.7 However, the health care workforce in the SCCR grew 
only by 0.02% in this period. Nationally in 2005, there were 0.6 doctors per 1,000 population, up 
from 0.4 in 1993. However, there were only 0.63 nurses per 1,000 population, similar to the 0.62 
in  1993.8 The  ratio  of  nurses  to  doctors  was  only  1.3,  compared  to  the  WHO  standard  of  4–5 
nurses per doctor (footnote 2, p. 13). Commendably, 94.8% of Viet Nam’s 10,679 CHSs have at 
least one trained health worker, often a midwife, and 70% have a doctor.9 While most deliveries 
are attended by a trained health worker, this is less common in the remote areas where most 
maternity  deaths  occur.  In  June  2007,  new  staffing  targets  were  set.  To  boost  the  number  of 
doctors to the target of 0.7 per 1,000 population and achieve the ratio of 3.5 nurses per doctor, 
the workforce would need to grow at a combined 3.6% per annum. That is much faster than the 
current growth of the entire workforce.10

Access to Services 

F. 
 
16. 
For the rural poor, access to health care remains problematic. Maternal deaths illustrate 
the  problem.  While  maternal  deaths  also  reflect  the  risks  of  living  in  remote  areas,  nearly  half 
were  due  to  delays  in  decision  making,  identifying  mothers  at  risk,  and  providing  essential 
treatment.17 Ethnic minorities tend to seek health services less often. Customs, language, and 
literacy also have an impact, and especially for minority women, of which one in four is unable 
to read. Public education on common health problems and services has often not been adjusted 
to the special needs of disadvantaged groups. A major thrust of the Government’s health sector 
plan  is  to  consolidate  and  complete  the  grassroots  health  network  to  carry  out  primary  health 
care  services  (footnote  2,  pp.35–37).  Plans  include  upgrading  the  facilities,  equipment,  and 
staffing of CHSs. MOH plans to have 1–2 VHWs in each village with at least a primary level of 
training  qualification  and  a  doctor  in  80%  of  all  CHSs  by  2010  and  in  100%  by  2020.  There 
should  be  at  least  one  female  staff  member  in  every  CHS  with  training  in  maternal  care. 
Upgrading the skills of CHS staff and VHWs are priorities for achieving MDGs. 
 
17.  While physical and social factors influence access, affordability of health care is the most 
significant constraining factor. The predominance of user fees at all levels of the health system, 
coupled  with  the  cost  of  drugs  and  indirect  expenses  for  travel  and  accompanying  family 
members, can be a devastating financial burden for those surviving at a subsistence level. The 
introduction  of  health  insurance,  especially  the  health  care  funds  for  the  poor  (HCFP),  is

Health Services Management and Financing 

 
18.  While the HCFP has reduced financial barriers to health care, and consequently led to 
increases in poor people’s utilization of health services, it has contributed little to improving the 
quality  of  health  facilities,  the  training  and  compensation  of  health  staff,  or  the  supply  of 
equipment  and  drugs  at  health  facilities.  To  achieve  HCFP’s  intended  impact,  these  need 
addressing. The processing of claims and reimbursements for health services provided to HCFP 
beneficiaries has imposed a considerable burden on administrative staff at hospitals and other 
health  facilities.  Delays  in  reimbursements  increase  the  financial  burden  on  health  facilities. 
Therefore, there is a strong argument for streamlining these processes while standardizing and 
computerizing claim forms and procedures.   
       
 
G. 
 
Beginning in 1996 with the introduction of the State Budget Law, planning and budgeting 
19. 
functions for the health sector were gradually devolved to the provincial governments with some 
flexibility for allocation of resources. The provincial governments have authority over provincial 
health  services,  the  district  governments  over  district  health  services,  and  communes  over 
village  health  care.  MOH  retains  control  over  centrally  managed  preventive  and  commune 
health services, national health programs, and research. The Ministry of Finance provides funds 
directly  to  the  provinces.  Subsidies  from  the  central  budget  are  also  intended  to  resolve 
imbalances by increasing the financial capacity of poorer provinces.  
    
20. 
The  WHO  calculated  that  total  health  expenditure  per  person  was  D504,000  in  2005. 
Viet  Nam’s  public  health  spending  is  still  only  1.5%  of  gross  domestic  product.  Private 
expenditure  accounts  for  77%  of  total  expenditure.18 A  significant  share  of  private  expenditure 
occurs  at  public  establishments,  with  out-of-pocket  funds  supporting  most  health  spending.  In 
the  SCCR,  private  expenditure  accounts  for  about  40%–50%  of  all  expenditures.  Most  public 
spending  is  associated  with  curative  activities19 at  the  provincial  and  district  levels.  Preventive 
services comprise only 10–20% of overall provincial health expenditure.  
  
21. 
During project preparation, provincial health accounts, 5-year health sector development 
plans, and medium-term expenditure frameworks were prepared for the eight provinces in order 
to  understand  current  sources  and  uses  of  funds  and  to  plan  for  balanced  investment  as  per 
policy. The health accounts demonstrated the reliance of provincial health departments on user 
fees and insurance for curative services. The process showed that planning is still input-driven 
rather  than  results-based,  with  a  major  local  priority  for  investment  in  civil  works.  Projected 
expenditures  during  2006–2010  exceeded  resources  in  all  categories  in  all  provinces.  The 
observed  resource  gaps  and  expenditure  imbalances  demonstrate  the  needs  to  (i)  further 
strengthen  evidence-based  decision  making,  service  delivery  efficiency,  and  allocative 
efficiency;  (ii) increase  health’s  share  of  overall  public  expenditure;  and  (iii)  mobilize  private 
investment.

poverty  remain.  In  2004,  the  incidence  of  poverty  was  26.4%  in  rural  areas  but  13.7%  in  urban  areas.  While  food

minorities,  in  particular,  have  not  kept  apace  of  the  economic  progress  experienced  by  others.  Similarly,  the  health

The  remoteness  of  many  rural  communities  and  the  unavailability  of  skilled  health  workers  contribute  significantly  to

access to quality care remains limited for these groups. Viet Nam’s health system is burdened by an infrastructure that 
is  old,  deteriorated,  and  poorly  equipped,  with  inadequate  systems  for  water  and  waste  management  and  infection 
control.  The  facilities  and  equipment  at  most  district  hospitals  are  old  and  degraded.  Provincial  hospitals  are 
overwhelmed,  with  overcrowded  wards  and  large  volumes  of  outpatients.  Many  commune  health  stations  in  the

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
Although  economic  growth  has  benefited  most  of  society,  the  level  of  inequality,  including  for  health  status,  has 
increased.  The  poverty  incidence  in  rural  areas  remains  significantly  higher  than  in  urban  areas,  and  61%  of  ethnic 
minority  households  lived  below  the  poverty  line  in  2002  compared  with  14%  of  Kinh  and  Chinese  households. 
Similarly, the health status of the rural population and ethnic minorities is significantly worse than in urban areas. Based 
on a 1999 study, the infant mortality rate was 69 per 1,000 live births for ethnic Gia Rai, 56 for ethnic H’mong, and 21 
for  the  majority  Kinh  population.  In  2004,  4%  of  Kinh  and  Chinese  children  under  5  were  severely  malnourished 
compared  to  33%  of  ethnic  minority  children.  A  Ministry  of  Health  study  conducted  in  2000–2001  found  maternal 
mortality  ratios  of  79  per  100,000  live  births  in  urban  areas,  145  in  rural  areas,  269  in  the  mountainous  and  midland 
areas, and 81 for Kinh compared to 316 among ethnic minorities. The proportion of ethnic minority people belonging to 
commune  health  centers  with  a  medical  doctor  is  only  30%,  compared  to  63%  for  Kinh  or  Chinese  people.  There  is 
also a shortage of qualified health care professionals from ethnic minorities who can bridge the language and culture 
gap  in  providing  health  services  in  certain  areas.  The  public  health  system  thus  faces  considerable  challenges  in 
protecting the health of poor and vulnerable groups and in responding to the changing patterns of disease associated 
with ongoing social, demographic, and epidemiological transitions.  
 
There is significant potential for improving health outcomes among the poor and ethnic groups in the project area. The 
Project will upgrade health facilities and equipment and increase the capacity of health workers to provide quality care. 
To  help  increase  the  number  of  women  and  ethnic  minority  health  workers,  the  Project  will  assist  each  province  to 
develop gender and ethnic minority action plans with focused interventions to ensure they reach targets for women and 
ethnic  minorities  in  training  courses.  Health  workers  serving  ethnic  minority  communities  will  be  given  priority  for 
training,  and  programs  will  include  topics  that  disproportionately  affect  ethnic  minorities.  The  Project  will  also 
specifically  address  quality  of  care  issues  in  remote  and  poor  commune  health  stations,  where  lack  of  staff  is  a 
problem, and will provide scholarships for local school leavers to attend health worker training at provincial secondary 
medical  schools  or  colleges  in  the  SCCR.  The  poorest  communes,  many  of  them  with  significant  ethnic  minority 
populations having limited access to services and poor health indicators, will be targeted to receive training for village 
health workers, health and nutrition promotion, and assistance to reduce financial barriers to health care.

Legal Framework and Principles 

The  ethnic  minority  strategy  is  based  on  Vietnamese  laws  and  ADB’s  Policy  on 
6. 
Indigenous  Peoples  (1998).  ADB’s  policy  aims  to  protect  ethnic  minorities  from  the  adverse 
impacts  of  development  and  to  ensure  that  they  benefit  from  development  projects  and 
programs.  ADB’s  Operations  Manual  section  on  indigenous  peoples  outlines  ADB  procedures 
and operational guidelines.5  

7. 
Viet Nam has a comprehensive legal framework for social equality. The Comprehensive 
Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy for 2001–2010 sets 11 goals, of which 7 deal directly 
with  issues  of  gender  and  ethnic  minorities  and  2  with  issues  of  vulnerability,  poverty 
eradication, and ethnic culture preservation: (i) achieve better education for all; (ii) reach gender 
equality  and  empower  women;  (iii)  reduce  infant  and  child  mortality;  (iv)  improve  maternal 
health;  (v)  combat  HIV/AIDS,  malaria,  and  other  communicable  diseases;  (vi)  reduce 
vulnerability; and (vii) eradicate poverty and preserve ethnic minority culture. Key stakeholders 
for the development of ethnic minorities include the Ministry of Health; Ministry of Labor, Invalids 
and Social Affairs; and the National Institute of Linguistics. The Committee for Ethnic Minority is 
responsible for coordinating ethnic issues and developing and implementing policies for ethnic 
minority groups in mountainous regions.  
 
8. 
The  Government  has  a  stated  commitment  to  improving  health  care  for  the  ethnic 
minority  population.  Directive  No.  6  of  22  January  2002  of  the  Central  Executive  Committee 
emphasizes  the  priority  of  health  care  in  mountainous  and  remote  areas,  and  particularly  for 
ethnic minorities. The Ministry of Health has issued Decision 370/2002 promoting health care at 
the commune level for 2001–2010, and its Decision 139 entitles ethnic minorities to free health 
care that is financed through the national budget.

9. 
The ethnic minority strategy ensures that all ethnic minority groups share proportionately 
in project benefits and protects them from any adverse effects from the Project. During project 
implementation,  the  provinces  will  review  the  socioeconomic  and  demographic  profiles  of  the 
target communities with respect to ethnicity. Using ADB’s checklist on indigenous peoples, the 
potential effects of the Project will be assessed for all ethnic minorities, potential impacts will be 
identified, and measures to mitigate these impacts will be incorporated into the detailed design 
of  each  subproject.  Budget  will  be  made  available  to  support  the  implementation  of  specific 
actions. Ethnic minorities that are affected by land acquisition and resettlement are eligible for 
the same entitlements and levels of compensation, regardless of ethnicity or gender.

Implementation  arrangements  and  estimated  costs  of  the  ethnic  minority  strategy  are 
integrated  into  the  Project’s  overall  arrangements  and  total  budget.  Representatives  from  the 
Committee  of  Ethnic  Minority  and  the  Viet  Nam  Women’s  Union  will  play  a  critical  role  in 
facilitating  participation  by  all  ethnic  minority  groups  in  project  activities  and  will  be  invited  to

ethnic  minorities.  The  midterm  review  mission  will  consider  past  updates  and  make
